msContents.summary: Epitaph of Nedymos and his family members, in hexameters and trimeters

div.head: α. 2543
div.p: My parents cried over my body around the unfeeling grave, since this is the honor due to the dead, but my soul left for its just destination. My name was Nedymos, a gentle child of the Italian Adae. I did not live for a long time, but I was born to live for only a few years; unstable time, you did not go back, but followed your own course; whatever destiny one is allotted, he fulfills it; and that is the case even for kings. My father Zosimos wrote this for me, and in his longing for me forgot about my immortal soul.

div.head: β. 2544
div.p: I am a marble stone, I bear a man in my belly, Nedymos; he is sleeping beautifully and in the company of the dead; the people honored him with a gold crown. The council did this in consolation to his son; the body of a lion crouches over this man dear to Ares. His son Zosimos wrote this, because indeed this is the honor due to the dead...And whoever would dare to place a body in my belly, to separate the father from his son, who I keep in my belly, will be fined a large sum payable to the city and to the treasury.

div.head: γ. 2545
div.p: My load is full; this is well. For Nedymos lies here in my belly and from this child a son was born, named Nedymos, and now the third, Zosimus, father of this child. Let one of the gods grant me to be closed and without seams; if someone reaches to open me, let his hopes bear no fruit, may he have no grandchildren, but may his whole lineage be completely uprooted.
